hints_html:
Let \(\displaystyle n = 2^{k}m\). First, recall

\(\displaystyle \sigma(n) = \sum_{d \mid n}d\)

is a multiplicative function. The condition that n is an even perfect number translates to \(\displaystyle 2n = \sigma(n)\).

Show that \(\displaystyle 2^{k+1}-1\mid m\) so that \(\displaystyle m = (2^{k+1}-1)M\) for some integer M.

A final piece of advice, notice that both m and M are divisors of m. Hence \(\displaystyle \sigma(m) \geq m + M\).

sols_html:
Let \(\displaystyle n = 2^{k}m\) with k at least 1. Further, let

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle \sigma(n) = \sum_{d \mid n}d\end{aligned}\]

and recall that this function is multiplicative (the sum is over positive divisors of n). Since we are given that n is an even perfect number, we know that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle 2n = \sigma(n).\end{aligned}\]

Next, we use the multiplicativity of \(\displaystyle \sigma\) and see that

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle 2^{k+1}m = 2n = \sigma(n) = \sigma(2^{k}m) = \sigma(2^{k})\sigma(m) = (1 + 2 + 2^{2} + ... + 2^{k})\sigma(m) = (2^{k+1}-1)\sigma(m).\end{aligned}\]

Since \(\displaystyle \gcd(2^{k+1},2^{k+1}-1) = 1\), we see that \(\displaystyle (2^{k+1}-1)\mid m\). Let M be an integer such that \(\displaystyle m = (2^{k+1}-1)M\). Substituting this into the above yields

\(\displaystyle 2^{k+1}(2^{k+1}-1)M = 2^{k+1}m = (2^{k+1}-1)\sigma(m)\).

Cancelling on both sides yields

\(\displaystyle 2^{k+1}M = \sigma(m)\).

Using the fact that both m and M are divisors of m (and hence are terms inside the expansion of \(\displaystyle \sigma(m)\), we have that

\(\displaystyle 2^{k+1}M = \sigma(m) \geq m + M = (2^{k+1}-1)M + M = 2^{k+1}M\).

Thus, the greater than sign is in fact an equality. This means that \(\displaystyle \sigma(m)\) has only two factors, namely m and M. Since \(\displaystyle m > M\), we must have that \(\displaystyle M=1\) and so \(\displaystyle m = (2^{k+1}-1)M = 2^{k+1}-1\). As m has only two prime factors, we also know that \(\displaystyle m = 2^{k+1}-1\) is prime. This completes the proof.

statement_html:
If \(\displaystyle n \in \mathbb{N}\) is an even perfect number, then there exists a \(\displaystyle k \in \mathbb{N}\) such that \(\displaystyle 2^{k+1}-1\) is a prime number and

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle n = 2^{k}(2^{k+1}-1)\end{aligned}\]
